description: Two anthropomorphized boomerangs, depicted with human limbs and clothing, are shown in a domestic setting with one preparing to leave. The departing boomerang, wearing glasses and carrying a suitcase, stands before a house door. The boomerang in the doorway, arms crossed, predicts the traveler will inevitably return shortly after leaving. This scene employs absurdism by portraying inanimate objects as people attempting a trip. The irony lies in the prediction being based on the fundamental, inescapable nature of a boomerang, making the attempted journey inherently futile and highlighting the theme of inescapable identity.
caption: “Ha! Just like every time, you’ll get about a hundred yards out, make a big arc, and start heading back.”
